messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] an interesting day
messages.msgSnippet: Just looking at good pictures of good pieces did wonders for me. Perhaps you should suggest that he get a couple of good books and surf the web a bit more.
messages.messageBody:
Just looking at good pictures of good pieces did wonders for me.

Perhaps you should suggest that he get a couple of good books and surf
the web a bit more. Cary's pix are unparalelled.

Db wrote a nice paper on spotting the hk crappers on ebay as well, if he
wants to shop there.

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Richard Turner [mailto:ikkanshi@...]
Verzonden: donderdag 1 mei 2003 14:44
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: [nihontostudy] an interesting day


Greetings all, today I had an interesting day indeed. I got to see one
of those Hong Kong Crappers up close and personal. I had a new
acquaintance make a 5 hour drive up from the southern part of the state
today to meet and greet and share his new sword with me. A young man in
his late teens. He was lucky in the sense that he didn't pay for this
sword, it was a gift, but someone bought it for him, mores the pity for
them.
It was decked out in what appeared to be standard gunto mount's that
turned out to be very poorly made indeed. The blade really isn't worthy
of mention, very poorly acid etched hamon, cheap old iron that had been
ground into shape. The mei looked like it was scratched out with a nail
or something. It was so badly made I couldn't believe it. Still, he
hangs it on his wall and enjoys it for what it is at the moment.

He want's to come to one of the local auctions later in the year. I
didn't have anything to show him as we met at my office but I said when
he sees something that is properly made he will understand more, for now
his cheap and nasty HKC can hang on his wall and he can dream of betters
things ahead.

Maybe with luck, in a few month's time we will have another convert in
our midst.

cheers all

Rich T

messages.subject: an interesting day
messages.msgSnippet: Greetings all, today I had an interesting day indeed. I got to see one of those Hong Kong Crappers up close and personal. I had a new acquaintance make a 5
messages.messageBody:
Greetings all, today I had an interesting day indeed. I got to see one of those Hong Kong Crappers up close and personal. I had a new acquaintance make a 5 hour drive up from the southern part of the state today to meet and greet and share his new sword with me. A young man in his late teens. He was lucky in the sense that he didn't pay for this sword, it was a gift, but someone bought it for him, mores the pity for them.
It was decked out in what appeared to be standard gunto mount's that turned out to be very poorly made indeed. The blade really isn't worthy of mention, very poorly acid etched hamon, cheap old iron that had been ground into shape. The mei looked like it was scratched out with a nail or something. It was so badly made I couldn't believe it. Still, he hangs it on his wall and enjoys it for what it is at the moment.

He want's to come to one of the local auctions later in the year. I didn't have anything to show him as we met at my office but I said when he sees something that is properly made he will understand more, for now his cheap and nasty HKC can hang on his wall and he can dream of betters things ahead.

Maybe with luck, in a few month's time we will have another convert in our midst.

cheers all

Rich T
